chapter.title: Installation
chapter.para: Assuming you're installing Boost.Build from released source distribution, the following steps are needed. All paths are given relatively to Boost.Build root directory, which is the directory with the document you are reading.

listitem.simpara: Go to "jam_src" directory and build Boost.Jam. Two convenient scripts are provided, "build.sh" (for Unix systems) and "build.bat" (for Windows). Run the appropriate one and Boost.Jam will be built to directory bin.{platform_name}.. The Boost.Jam documentation has more details in case you need them.

listitem.para:
Place the Boost.Jam binary, called "bjam" or "bjam.exe", somewhere in your PATH. Go to the root directory of Boost.Build and run "bjam --version". You should get
Boost.Build V2 (Milestone N)
(where N is the version you've downloaded).

listitem.simpara: Configure toolsets to use. Open the user-config.jam file and follow instructions there to specify what compiles/libraries you have and where they are located.
You should now be able to go to example/hello, and run bjam there. A simple application will be built. You can also play with other projects in example.

chapter.para: If you use Boost distribution, or Boost CVS, the Boost.Build root is located at $boost_root/tools/build/v2 and the installation steps are the same. However, don't skip the bjam rebuilding step, even if you have a previous version. CVS version of Boost.Build requires CVS version of Boost.Jam.
When starting a new project which uses Boost.Build, you need to make sure that build system can be found. There are two ways.

listitem.simpara: Set enviromnetal variable BOOST_BUILD_PATH to the absolute path to Boost.Build installation directory.

chapter.para: If you're trying to use Boost.Build V2 on Boost itself, please note that when building Boost, V1 is used by default. You'd have to add --v2 command line option to all "bjam" invocations.
